# Introduction

<!-- Establish a territory : claim centrality, make topic generalizations, review items of previous research -->

Video games intended for educational purposes (Educational Video Games, EdVG) are fascinating creations. Their guiding principle is to translate an educational goal while offering a unique and engaging play experience. However, this play experience must have a certain degree of learning outcome, if not the EdVG may remain in limbo. Using grounded models (for an overview, see @wiemeyer_etal_2016) or practice-based experiences, EdVG designers hypothesize that the created learning situation leads to learning outcomes. Furthermore, these situations hold pivotal positions in the game play. In that respect, prior learning hypotheses must be tested. Data collection combined with data analysis may provide observable indicators on players' actions at play. One may say âIf you cannot measure it, you cannot improve itâ.

## Educational Video Games

// What is Educational Video Games? From SVG and different types of SVG, there EdVG, 

We often refer to as serious video games (SVG), games designed to offer a pedagogical use. However, we will use the term epistemic video game (EpVG) which is more precise than an SVG in a sense that it takes into account the situation and the subjectivity of the game creates and the interactions it allows (@sanchez_2022).

More than simple users, they are players because the game allow concrete action and decision making throughout the game. 

We want to make the reader attentive to the term 'traces', which is used in the present work to qualify any game data about players' interactions with the system and does not include metadata or hardware specifications for example.

## PLAY project

<!-- Occupying the niche : outlining purposes, announcing the present research, announcing principal findings, indicating structure -->

<!-- //Ici rÃ©dige environ une page sur le projet, ses enjeux, les rÃ©sultats attendus du projet : repenser les visites scolaires au musÃ©e avec des approches ludiques  & travailler sur des problÃ¨mes complexes en lien avec des thÃ©matiques sociÃ©tales  -->

<!-- Le projet PLAY qui a pour objectif de comprendre comment la ludicisation de visites scolaires au musÃ©e, permet  Ã  des apprenants de sâengager dans la rÃ©solution de problÃ¨mes complexes et non dÃ©terministes et, ce faisant,  de dÃ©velopper leur rapport au savoir. -->

This master thesis thus focuses on the analysis of digital traces. The current work is part of the PLAY project (https://www.lip-unige.ch/project/play-playing-for-learning-an-economic-approach-to-human-behavior/) which aims at understanding museum scholar visits under the lens of ludicisation. Instead of focusing on the components making a system more engaging (i.e. gamification, defined as "the use of game design elements in non-game contexts", @deterding_etal_2011), here ludicisation take a step back and broaden the focus to the situation, involving not only the game but also the player(s), the context(s) and their interactions. The result of ludicisation is to convert of an ordinary situation into a perceived play situation (@genvo_2013). Once play is made central, players' engagement is met and, in return, allows to alter their relation to knowledge. Thus, the aim of the PLAY project is to understand how ludicisation of museum scholar visits allows learners to engage in solving complex and non-deterministic problems.

# Methods

## AL2049

AL2049 is an open-ended construction and resource management simulation game. It can be mirrored with commercially-available video games such as SimCity, ThemePark or Cities:Skylines. AL2049 is currently playable at the Alimentarium, a food museum based in Vevey (Switzerland, more info : https://www.alimentarium.org/fr/activities/al2049-lescape-game-de-lalimentarium). This game has been created using design-based research (@oliveira_etal_2022).

The game is played on tablets, by groups of three to four people. Participantsâ age ranges from r min(dfage). The game first appears to the players with a map of the museum. The map shows locked **zones**. Players must physically walk to the different places of the museum to take a picture of the place and unlock the zone. Once done, players must choose between different types of **energy** to build different forms of **facilities**. Energy used can be either petrol, solar or human. Facilities ranges from â¦ .

The game is supervised by a Game Master (âGMâ, usually a museum worker who has knowledge on the game). At the beginning the game, the latter sets the main goal as : feeding everyone. Participants are free to move around the museum for X minutes. Once they come back, the GM enable a new game feature â¦

AL2049 aims at developing players skill to think about food system complexity.

The data used for this Masters' thesis were collected by ...

AL2049, an educational video game, follows the later statements. It has been played by thousands of pupilsâ groups in a museum and digital traces have been collected from their play session. Its development originates from research-based design, that is, researchers, the curator of the Alimentarium museum and game developers worked hand in hand to create AL2049. One of its educational purposes is to âunderstand the complex relationships between food production system componentsâ (Oliveira et al., 2022). 

The aim of the team is to test whether this later educational goal can be tested through the gameplay data. I will focus on one way to test it. How players change their strategies throughout the game session. It will thus be a hint to their understanding of the complex relationships between food production system components.

## A priori analysis

An a priori analysis was performed before the current analysis of digital traces. It involved a researcher involved in the whole design process of AL2049. We decomposed complexity into nine complexity criteria for food production systems (for details, see 'Complexity' chapter). The nine criteria are : 1) Nonlinearity, 2) Feedback, 3) Spontaneous order, 4) Robustness and lack of central control, 5) Emergence, 6) Hierarchical organisation, 7) Numerosity, 8) Systemicity (interdependence), 9) Incertainty and unpredictability. For each criteria, first, we described how the chosen complexity criteria was present in AL2049 (e.g., how nonlinearity was part of the game). Second, the expected digital trace linked to the situation (e.g., the number of change in the 'FoodProduction' variable). Third, an a priori hypothesis involving the trace (e.g., in Phase I, 'FoodProduction' is significantly chosen by players over the other variables).

# Lol

From One to Many Play Strategies. Analyzing Trace Data from AL2049, an Educational Video Game about Food Production Complexity.
Author : Kenneth Rioja
Supervisors : Eric Sanchez (TECFA, UNIGE), Simon Morard (TECFA, UNIGE)
Development Master
Introduction

Educational Video Games (EdVG) are fascinating yet challenging creations. Their guiding principle is to translate an educational goal into a unique and engaging play experience . However, this play experience must have a certain degree of learning outcome, if not its educational benefit can be close to zero. Using generic and domain-specific models (for an overview, see Wiemeyer et al., 2016) as well as practice-based experiences (e.g., design-based research, Sloane, 2017; Squire, 2005), EdVG designers are told to create a learning situation leading to learning outcomes. Furthermore, these situations hold pivotal positions in the gameplay. In that respect, prior learning hypotheses must be tested. Data collection and data analysis are a way to provide observable indicators on players' actions at play. One may say âIf you cannot measure it, you cannot improve itâ.

AL2049, an EdVG about food production, follows the later statements. It has been played by thousands of pupilsâ groups in a museum and digital traces have been collected from their play session. Its development originates from research-based design, that is, researchers, the curator of the Alimentarium museum and game developers worked hand in hand to create AL2049. One of its educational purposes is to âunderstand the complex relationships between food production system componentsâ (Oliveira et al., 2022). 

The game seeks to change playersâ relationship to knowledge about food production complexity by playing a non-deterministic game. Players advance through the game without the correct answer, and this type of problem is called ill-structured problem (Jonassen, 2000). The goal of this Masters thesis is to find what indicators can be linked to their comprehension of food production complexity and see whether their strategies are changing over time thanks to these indicators. It will thus be a way to bring to light their understanding of the complex relationships between food production system components.
Litterature Review

AL2049 is an EdVG aiming at making players aware of the food production complexity. Defining complexity is undoubtedly a complex task. The Cambridge Dictionary (2024) describes it as: âthe state of having many parts and being difficult to understand or find an answer toâ. In the literature, we can find the concept of complexity broke down into a list of seven properties: Nonlinear, Feedback, Spontaneous Order, Robustness, Emergence, Hierarchical Organization and Numerosity (Ladyman et al., 2013). Wikipedia (2024) adds an interesting variation: âDefinitions of complexity often depend on the concept of a "system"â. AL2049 refers to the food production system and how complex it is. The game is thus a non-exhaustive model of it and, like science, reductionism (i.e., decomposing a system into multiple parts to trying to understand it) has been used to explain complexity. However, there are two types of system modelling: a first is called analytic modelling which isolates the atoms of an ensemble whereas systemic modelling binds elements of a same entity (Lugan, 2009). AL2049 sits in the second system modelling and on top of that offers the players to solve an ill-structured problem. For Jonassen (2000), it appears ill-structured because of: â 1) its problem elements which are unknown or not known with any degree of confidence (Wood, 1983, cited by Jonassen, 2000); 2) its multiple solution, solution paths, or no solutions at all (Kitchner, 1983, cited by Jonassen, 2000); 3) the multiple criteria for evaluating solutions, so there is uncertainty about which concepts, rules, and principles are necessary for the solution and how they are organized; and 4) often requires learners to make judgments and express personal opinions or beliefs about the problem, so ill-structured problems are uniquely human interpersonal activities (Meacham & Emont, 1989, cited by Jonassen, 2000).â
Analyses of play traces from an EdVG built on ill-structured problems is not a common domain. Indeed, AL2049, as an ill-structured problem, focuses more on âthe decision, articulation and argumentationâ and âdilemnas with no verifiably correct solutionâ (Jonassen, 2000). The expected learning outcome of AL2049 is called epistemic development. It is âthe ability to grasp the complexity of a problem, to identify themselves as being able to elaborate solutions to this problem and to develop arguments that justifies the choices doneâ (free translation from Sanchez, 2022). Epistemic development is often analyzed through quantitative analyses (Cabellos & Pozo, 2023). Furthermore, in Learning Analytics, the âanalysis and representation of data about learners in order to improve learningâ (Clow, 2013), as well as Game / Gameplay / Play / Player analytics (for a recent comprehensive review and classification of game analytics, see Su et al., 2021), pletoras of analyses have been developped for specific games (Lankoski & BjÃ¶rk, 2015; Lang et al., 2022; Seif El-Nasr, 2013), but none have focused on epistemic development. 
â
Research Question

This development Masters thesis is therefore concerned with the problem of finding a methodology to set down indicators from a quantitative point of view supporting epistemic development.

Our main research question is âHow the game allow players to grasp the food system complexity stakes and how do they interact with themâ

Specific RQ1: What game indicators allow to detect a change in strategy ?

Specific RQ2: How to visualize these game indicators to allow researchers to determine the players' analytic or systemic approach to complexity?

Firstly, how are the indicators of complexity translated into the traces of the AL2049 game? (translation of the complexity of the food system into the game). Secondly, how do players' strategies change in the face of the complexity of the food production system? (people's ability to understand the complex relationships between the components of the food production system).
